awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Sweeping Process Framework to Control the Dynamics of Elastoplastic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Accurate and efficient prediction of the mechanical behavior of materials under extreme conditions is becoming increasingly crucial for the design of novel materials that address the grand challenges in security, energy and health. The examples range from micron-sized solder joints in micro-chips to crucial structural parts of airplanes. Localized plastic (i.e. irreversible) deformations that the material develops under cyclic loading represent the most typical route to the loss of performance and material's failure. Recently, lattices of connected springs became widely used to model plastic deformations of modern materials under cyclic loading. However, only elastic (i.e. reversible) deformations of lattice spring models can be controlled within the currently available theory. This award supports the development of a mathematical theory with the capability to predict and influence the asymptotic behavior of lattice spring models that are allowed to deform both elastically and plastically (termed elastoplastically). The new mathematical framework will provide a revolutionary tool to accelerate computation of the regions where the plastic deformations concentrate (known to cause crack initialization) and will make it computationally feasible to design materials with superior service lifetime. The designed materials (e.g., super fatigue resistant alloys) can be eventually manufactured to impact such industries as aerospace, automobile, microelectronics and biomedical. Therefore, the results from this research will benefit the U.S. society and national security. The multi-disciplinary collaboration will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and positively impact mathematical and engineering education.

Differential equations with moving polyhedral constraints (commonly known as sweeping processes) will be used to model the lattices of elastoplastic springs under cyclic loading. By developing a theory of stability and bifurcations for sweeping processes, this project will identify the mechanical parameters of lattice spring models that ensure a unique periodic response (finite-time stable or asymptotic) or co-existing periodic responses (isolated or not) to a cyclic loading given. The dynamical behavior found will be used to efficiently compute the asymptotic distribution of plastic deformations. The performance of this tool will be demonstrated by applying it to the design of such heterogeneous materials for which the distribution of plastic deformations (in the response to cyclic loading) stays as uniform as possible. In this design, the Volume-Compensated Lattice-Particle method will be utilized to map the digital representation of the material microstructure to a lattice spring model. The design will be experimentally validated using 3D-printed sample composite materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
In this project, a sweeping process theory (SPT) has been developed to predictively model and control the dynamics of elastoplastic spring network systems and subsequently applied to significantly accelerate computer simulations and modeling of complex heterogeneous materials involving elastoplastic behaviors, including fatigue fracture of composites, mechanical signaling in bio-polymer networks, and nonlinear mechanical behaviors of disordered network materials. The SPT allows one to precisely predict the on-set of plasticity of individual springs in the systems, which in turn leads to the development of a high-efficient "leap-frog" computational framework to skip the tiny time steps typically required for nonlinear simulations and directly jump from one plastic event to the next plastic events, which are responsible for the overall nonlinear mechanical behavior of the system. This framework significantly improves both computational efficiency and accuracy and has been successfully employed to model nonlinear mechanical behaviors of composites, disordered networks materials, and biopolymer networks. These studies reveal the local deformation and failure mechanics of the materials, and significantly enhance our understanding on the effects of local heterogeneity and anisotropy of the system on the overall nonlinear mechanical behaviors for their design and optimization. The computational framework has been experimentally tested via 3D printed polymer network materials using state-of-art 3D printers available at Advanced Manufacturing Center at ASU. The results generated in the project have been disseminated to communities, including journal and conference papers and presentations. Computer codes and programs for the SPT framework for mechanical analysis of complex materials and disordered network materials, which have been pushed to Github repository and are made publicly available.

An international workshop "Workshop on the Intersection of Set-Valued Analysis, Plasticity, and Friction" has been co-organized together with the UT Dallas team to disseminate the results and brainstorm new ideas. Research opportunities have been provided to undergraduate, graduate students and a short-term postdoctoral researcher, with diverse background from materials, physics and mathematics. A course module based on the SPT framework was created and incorporated into the computational materials course taught at ASU. The accelerated SPT simulation tools can serve as a crucial component in integrated computational material engineering (ICME) framework, which in turn can serve a virtual platform for material testing, design and optimization. It is expected the tools developed in this project will aid the design and optimization of multi-functional composites with applications in soft robotics, high-fatigue resistant alloys with applications in aerospace engineering and deepen our understanding of mechanical signaling in cell-host systems for better tumor treatment. Through this project, a long-term collaboration will be established between UT Dallas and ASU. This allows the PIs to continue the collaboration and expand their research efforts.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2022
Modified by: Yang Jiao
